head.title: Northwestern Business Dean Plans to Step Down Next Year

hedline.hl1: Northwestern Business Dean Plans to Step Down Next Year

abstract.p: Donald P Jacobs announces retirement as dean of Northwestern University's business school (S)

block.p: Donald P. Jacobs, one of the most influential people in management education, will step down next spring after a quarter-century as the dean of Northwestern University's business school, the university announced yesterday.
Mr. Jacobs, 73, has served longer than any current major university president or other business school dean, higher education experts said.

Donald P. Jacobs, one of the most influential people in management education, will step down next spring after a quarter-century as the dean of Northwestern University's business school, the university announced yesterday.
Mr. Jacobs, 73, has served longer than any current major university president or other business school dean, higher education experts said.

Since taking over in 1975 -- reluctantly, and only after three other candidates turned down the job -- Mr. Jacobs oversaw changes that many rival schools have since imitated. The Kellogg Graduate School of Management, as it is now known, built an executive education center, complete with a hotel, that has brought a financial windfall to the school. Kellogg was also among the first business schools to interview all of its applicants and to encourage students to play a major role in designing the curriculum.

As a result, Mr. Jacobs said yesterday, people began to see that the ideal student -- and executive -- is not a rugged individual but rather ''one who is a team player and plays a number of leadership roles on campus.''
During his tenure, Kellogg also climbed in the rankings published by national magazines.
Mr. Jacobs was a banking expert on the school's faculty before becoming the dean. He also served as the chairman of Amtrak in the late 1970's.

He said he began to consider retirement after he became ill last spring, and though he has recovered in recent months, he still decided to step aside. ''It means I can go back and be a professor again before time runs out,'' said Mr. Jacobs, who now teaches management.
Northwestern said it would appoint a search committee and consider both internal and external candidates.
